question:
Trishulganga is a stream of the river:

SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)
solution:
Trishulganga is a stream of the Gandak River, which originates in the Nepal Himalayas and flows through Bihar before joining the Ganga. The Trishulganga joins the Gandak in Nepal, making it one of its Himalayan tributaries. Gandak itself is an important left-bank tributary of the Ganga and is known for its hydroelectric potential and fertile plains. Questions on river tributaries are common in SSC exams due to their geographic and economic relevance.
  • Extra Information:

Gandak River is also known as the Narayani River in Nepal.

Major cities on its banks include Bettiah and Hajipur in Bihar.

It plays a key role in Indo-Nepal water-sharing agreements and irrigation.

The Gandak Barrage at Valmikinagar is crucial for irrigation and flood control.

question:
Select the odd one from the following saltwater lakes on the basis of their formation?

SSC MTS 09/10/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution: Sambhar Lake is the odd one out because it is a saltwater lake formed due to inland drainage in an arid region, primarily by tectonic activity. In contrast, Pulicat, Kolleru, and Chilika lakes are coastal lagoons formed by the deposition of sediments and the action of waves creating barrier spits along the coast. These three are influenced by marine processes, while Sambhar is entirely landlocked and located in Rajasthan, far from any coastlines.

question:
The Zaskar and the Nubra are tributaries of which river?

SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
The Zaskar and Nubra are important tributaries of the Indus River, which originates in Tibet and flows through Ladakh into Pakistan. The Zaskar River joins the Indus near Leh, while the Nubra River originates from the Siachen Glacier and merges with the Shyok River, which later meets the Indus. These rivers are part of the Trans-Himalayan drainage system and contribute significantly to the water volume of the upper Indus basin.
  • Extra Information:
    • The Indus River is one of the longest rivers in the world, flowing over 3,000 km.
    • It is the lifeline of Pakistan and crucial for the Indus Valley Civilization.
    • The Zaskar region is known for the Chadar Trek over the frozen river in winters.
    • The Indus Water Treaty between India and Pakistan governs the sharing of its waters.

question:
Which of the following rivers flows north of the Tropic of Cancer in India?

SSC MTS 30/10/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
The Yamuna River flows entirely north of the Tropic of Cancer, which passes approximately through the middle of India (near 23.5°N latitude). Originating from the Yamunotri Glacier in Uttarakhand, the Yamuna flows through the northern plains covering states like Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, Delhi, and Uttar Pradesh before merging with the Ganga at Prayagraj. The other rivers listed—Mahanadi, Tapi, and Penganga—flow south of or cross the Tropic of Cancer, mostly draining the peninsular region.
  • Extra Information:
    • The Tropic of Cancer passes through 8 Indian states, including Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, and West Bengal.
    • The Yamuna is the longest tributary of the Ganga and supports dense populations along its banks.
    • Major cities on Yamuna include Delhi, Agra, and Mathura.
    • Important tributaries of Yamuna: Tons, Hindon, Ken, and Chambal.

question:
What is the salt measurement in hypersaline lagoons?

SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
Hypersaline lagoons have a salinity level exceeding 100 parts per thousand (ppt), which is significantly higher than the average ocean salinity of about 35 ppt. These extreme salt concentrations occur due to high evaporation rates, low freshwater input, and restricted water circulation. Hypersaline environments are found in arid and semi-arid regions and often support only highly specialized microbial life due to the harsh chemical conditions.
  • Extra Information:
    • Examples of hypersaline water bodies: Dead Sea, Don Juan Pond (Antarctica), and Garabogazköl (Turkmenistan).
    • Such environments are useful for studying extremophiles and have industrial applications like salt extraction.
    • Normal seawater has a salinity of around 35 ppt; freshwater is less than 0.5 ppt.

question:
In which state of India is kund orTanka used for water harvesting ?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
Kund or Tanka is a traditional rainwater harvesting structure used in Rajasthan, especially in arid and semi-arid regions. These are underground or semi-underground tanks with a saucer-shaped catchment area designed to collect and store rainwater for drinking and domestic use. Due to low rainfall and high evaporation, Rajasthan has developed several indigenous water conservation methods like Kunds, Baoris, and Johads, making it a pioneer in community-based water management.
  • Extra Information:
    • Kunds are usually lined with lime or cement to prevent seepage and are covered to reduce evaporation and contamination.
    • These systems are still in use and have been revived under water conservation schemes like Jal Shakti Abhiyan.
    • Similar water harvesting systems in other states:
      • Eris in Tamil Nadu
      • Zabo in Nagaland
      • Ahar-Pyne in Bihar
      • Surangam in Kerala

question:
Which of the following is the transboundary river between India and Pakistan?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The Ravi River originates in Himachal Pradesh and flows into Pakistan, making it a transboundary river. It is part of the Indus River system and is governed under the Indus Waters Treaty, which allows India to use its waters, though the river continues into Pakistani territory.
  • Extra Information: The Ravi merges with the Chenab in Pakistan. The Ranjit Sagar Dam is built on it in India for irrigation and hydroelectric purposes.

question:
In which state of India was the Neeru-Meeru programme introduced for construction of water harvesting structures?

SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
The Neeru-Meeru programme was initiated in 2000 by the Government of Andhra Pradesh to promote rainwater harvesting and watershed development. It aimed to improve groundwater levels and ensure water availability through construction and restoration of water structures with community participation.

Extra Information:

  • Launched on 1st May 2000 during peak summer.
  • Focused on check dams, tanks, percolation pits, and desilting of tanks.
  • Encouraged people’s participation and inter-departmental coordination.
  • Implemented in drought-prone and semi-arid regions.
  • Played a major role in groundwater recharge and sustainable agriculture

question:
Identify a water-harvesting system found in Jaisalmer.

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
Solution: Khadins are traditional water-harvesting systems developed in the arid regions of Jaisalmer, Rajasthan. They consist of an embankment constructed to harvest surface runoff during the monsoon. The water slowly infiltrates and saturates the soil, allowing for crop cultivation without irrigation during the dry season.

Extra Information:

  • Designed by the Paliwal Brahmins centuries ago.
  • Ideal for runoff farming in low rainfall areas.
  • Prevents soil erosion and enhances groundwater recharge.
  • Typically used to grow crops like wheat, barley, and pulse

question:
Which of the following rivers marks the eastern-most boundary of the Himalayas?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The Brahmaputra River marks the eastern-most boundary of the Himalayas. It originates in Tibet as the Yarlung Tsangpo, enters Arunachal Pradesh through a deep gorge, and flows westward across Assam. Its sharp southward bend marks the end of the Himalayan range, making it a significant geographic boundary.

Extra Information:

  • Known as Tsangpo in Tibet, Siang/Dihang in Arunachal, and Brahmaputra in Assam.
  • Forms the eastern syntaxis of the Himalayas.
  • One of the largest rivers in terms of discharge in India.
  • Major tributaries include Subansiri, Dibang, and Lohit

question:
Which of the following peninsular rivers falls into the Arabian Sea?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
Solution: The Sabarmati River is one of the few major peninsular rivers that drains into the Arabian Sea. Originating from the Aravalli Hills in Rajasthan, it flows through Gujarat and empties into the Arabian Sea near the Gulf of Khambhat. Most other peninsular rivers, like the Mahanadi, Krishna, and Godavari, flow eastward into the Bay of Bengal.

Extra Information:

  • Total length is about 371 km, with a major portion in Gujarat.
  • Ahmedabad city is situated on its banks.
  • Major tributaries: Wakal, Hathmati, Watrak.
  • Sabarmati Riverfront Project is a notable urban development on its banks

question:
In the ancient temple of Mahadev at Mahabaleshwar, the spout emerging from the mouth of a cow statue is the source of which river basin?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The Krishna River originates from a cow-shaped spout (Gomukh) in the Mahadeva temple at Mahabaleshwar in Maharashtra. This symbolic emergence marks the beginning of the Krishna River, which is one of the major rivers in peninsular India and flows eastward into the Bay of Bengal.

Extra Information:

  1. The Krishna River is the fourth longest river in India after the Ganga, Godavari, and Yamuna.
  2. Major tributaries include the Bhima, Tungabhadra, and Koyna rivers.
  3. The river flows through Maharashtra, Karnataka, Telangana, and Andhra Pradesh

question:
Which of the following are west flowing rivers?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
Mahi and Sabarmati are among the few rivers in India that flow westward into the Arabian Sea. While most major Indian rivers flow eastward into the Bay of Bengal, these rivers originate in central India and Rajasthan respectively and take a westerly course due to regional topography.

Extra Information:

  1. The Mahi River is notable for flowing across the Tropic of Cancer twice.
  2. The Sabarmati River originates in the Aravalli Hills and flows through Gujarat.
  3. Both rivers empty into the Arabian Sea near the Gulf of Khambhat.

question:
Which of the following rivers is an east flowing river?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
Godavari is an east-flowing river that originates in the Western Ghats of Maharashtra and travels eastward across the Deccan Plateau to drain into the Bay of Bengal. It is India’s second longest river and is often referred to as the “Dakshin Ganga” due to its size and cultural significance.

Extra Information:

  1. The Godavari flows through Maharashtra, Telangana, Chhattisgarh, and Andhra Pradesh.
  2. Major tributaries include the Manjira, Indravati, and Pranhita rivers.
  3. The river supports agriculture, drinking water, and hydroelectric power across several states.

question:
‘Bhagirathi’ and ‘Alaknanda’ rivers confluence at:

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
The rivers Bhagirathi and Alaknanda meet at Devprayag in Uttarakhand, and from this confluence onward, the combined river is known as the Ganga. Devprayag is one of the Panch Prayags (five sacred river confluences) of the Alaknanda and holds great religious significance in Hinduism.

Extra Information:

  1. Bhagirathi is considered the source stream of the Ganga due to its mythological importance.
  2. Alaknanda has a greater length and discharge compared to Bhagirathi.
  3. Devprayag is a prominent pilgrimage site located in the Tehri Garhwal district of Uttarakhand.

question:
Which state of India has the maximum number of large dams?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
Maharashtra has the highest number of large dams in India, with over 2300 major dams as per the Central Water Commission. The state has extensively developed water infrastructure for irrigation, drinking water, and hydroelectricity to support its vast agricultural and industrial sectors.

Extra Information:

  1. Notable dams in Maharashtra include Jayakwadi, Koyna, and Ujjani.
  2. The state relies heavily on monsoon rains and dam reservoirs to manage water scarcity.
  3. Maharashtra’s topography supports both multipurpose and storage dams across river basins.

question:
In which group of states does the Luni River flow?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Bihar and West Bengal
option_2: Andhra Pradesh and Telangana
solution:
The Luni River originates from the Aravalli Hills near Ajmer in Rajasthan and flows southwest into the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat. It is the largest river in the arid region of Rajasthan and is known for its saline water, especially in the lower reaches, making it unsuitable for irrigation.

Extra Information:

  1. The Luni River is an endorheic river, meaning it does not drain into the sea.
  2. It covers a course of about 495 km before vanishing into marshy lands.
  3. Key tributaries include the Sukri, Jawai, and Bandi rivers

question:
Which of the following is NOT a tributary of the Ganga?

SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The Lohit River is not a tributary of the Ganga; it is a tributary of the Brahmaputra. Originating in the eastern Himalayas in Tibet, it enters India through Arunachal Pradesh and joins the Brahmaputra in Assam. In contrast, Yamuna, Gandak, and Kosi are all major tributaries of the Ganga River system.

Extra Information:

  1. The Lohit River flows through the Mishmi Hills and contributes to the eastern Brahmaputra basin.
  2. The Kosi and Gandak rivers originate in Nepal and often cause floods in Bihar.
  3. The Yamuna is the largest and most important right-bank tributary of the Ganga.

question:
The Aryans lived in the land known as ‘Sapta Sindhu’ (Land of the Seven Rivers). Which of the following was NOT a part of it?

SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
The Shipra River was not part of the Sapta Sindhu region, which referred to the land of seven rivers in the northwestern part of the Indian subcontinent during the Vedic period. The region mainly included rivers like the Indus, Ravi, Jhelum, Chenab, Beas, Sutlej, and Saraswati, which were considered sacred and central to early Aryan settlements.

Extra Information:

  1. The Shipra River flows through Madhya Pradesh and is associated with Ujjain and the Kumbh Mela.
  2. The Sapta Sindhu region largely corresponds to present-day Punjab and parts of Pakistan.
  3. The Saraswati River, though now extinct, held great spiritual significance in Vedic literature

question:
Which of the following rivers originates from the Himalayas?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The Ganga originates from the Gangotri Glacier in the western Himalayas in Uttarakhand, where it begins as the Bhagirathi River. It later joins with the Alaknanda at Devprayag to form the Ganga. As a perennial Himalayan river, it is primarily fed by glacial melt and rainfall, making it one of the most significant and sacred rivers in India.

Extra Information:

  1. The Ganga flows across northern India and Bangladesh before draining into the Bay of Bengal.
  2. It supports dense populations and fertile agricultural plains throughout its course.
  3. Unlike the Ganga, the Godavari, Tapi, and Narmada originate from the central Indian highlands.

question:
Subansiri, Jia Bharali, Dhansiriand Puthimari are the major tributaries of which river?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
Subansiri, Jia Bharali, Dhansiri, and Puthimari are important tributaries of the Brahmaputra River, which flows through Tibet (as Tsangpo), Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, and Bangladesh. These tributaries, mostly joining from the north and south, contribute significantly to the water volume and flood dynamics of the Brahmaputra.

Extra Information:

  1. The Subansiri is the largest tributary of the Brahmaputra and a major source of hydroelectric potential.
  2. Jia Bharali originates in Arunachal Pradesh and is known for its clear waters and scenic course.
  3. These tributaries play a crucial role in agriculture, biodiversity, and river navigation in Assam.

question:
On which river in India was the Somasila Dam built?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Somasila Dam is built on the Pennar River in the Nellore district of Andhra Pradesh. It is one of the largest reservoirs in the state and serves multiple purposes including irrigation, drinking water supply, and flood control, especially for the arid and semi-arid regions of southern Andhra Pradesh.

Extra Information:

  1. The Pennar River originates in the Nandi Hills of Karnataka and flows eastward into the Bay of Bengal.
  2. Somasila Reservoir has a gross storage capacity of over 2,000 million cubic meters.
  3. The dam plays a crucial role in supporting agriculture in Nellore and surrounding districts.

question:
The Bist Doab Canal System and Makhu Canal System are associated with which state of India?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
The Bist Doab Canal System and Makhu Canal System are key irrigation infrastructures located in Punjab. These canal systems draw water primarily from the Sutlej River and its associated irrigation networks, playing a vital role in supporting the state's agrarian economy, especially in regions between the Beas and Sutlej rivers.

Extra Information:

  1. The Bist Doab region lies between the Beas and Sutlej rivers, making it highly fertile and canal-dependent.
  2. Punjab’s extensive canal irrigation network is essential for wheat and paddy cultivation.
  3. These canals are part of the broader Indus Water Treaty arrangements involving India and Pakistan.

question:
The largest inland salt lake ‘Sambhar’ is located in the ______of India.

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
Sambhar Lake, India’s largest inland saltwater lake, is situated in the north-western part of the country, specifically in Rajasthan. It is a saline wetland and plays a crucial role in salt production. The lake receives water from seasonal rivers like Mendha and Rupangarh and is a vital ecological and economic zone.

Extra Information:

  1. Sambhar Lake lies southwest of Jaipur, near the Aravalli ranges.
  2. It is recognized under the Ramsar Convention as a wetland of international importance.
  3. The lake supports a rich birdlife, including migratory species like flamingos

question:
Which of the following rivers is called ‘Singi Khamban’ in Tibet?

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Indus River is known as ‘Singi Khamban’, meaning "Lion's Mouth," in Tibet. It originates from the Bokhar Chu glacier near Lake Mansarovar in Tibet and flows through India and Pakistan. The river holds great historical and geographical significance, especially as the cradle of the ancient Indus Valley Civilization.

Extra Information:

  1. The Indus enters India in Ladakh and then flows into Pakistan before reaching the Arabian Sea.
  2. It is one of the longest rivers in Asia, with several tributaries like Jhelum, Chenab, Ravi, Beas, and Sutlej.
  3. The Indus Water Treaty governs its use between India and Pakistan since 1960

question:
The Chilika Lake is located to the south of the ________ delta.

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
Chilika Lake, Asia’s largest brackish water lagoon, lies to the south of the Mahanadi River delta in the state of Odisha. This lake is connected to the Bay of Bengal and plays a significant role in coastal biodiversity, fisheries, and migratory bird conservation. It also supports local livelihoods through fishing and tourism.

Extra Information:

  1. Chilika is a designated Ramsar Site due to its ecological importance.
  2. It hosts over 160 species of birds during winter, including flamingos and pelicans.
  3. The lake’s ecosystem supports seagrasses, dolphins, and a variety of marine and freshwater species.

question:
Delhi ridge is the water divide between which of the following rivers?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Delhi Ridge acts as a natural water divide between the Ganges and Indus river systems. This ridge is an extension of the Aravalli hills and influences the direction of surface water flow—channeling it either towards the Ganges basin in the east or the Indus basin in the west.

Extra Information:

  1. The Delhi Ridge plays an essential role in controlling soil erosion and maintaining ecological balance in the Delhi region.
  2. It is geologically part of the ancient Aravalli Range and extends into the capital as a forested area.
  3. This divide influences drainage patterns and water availability in northern India

question:
Which of the following pairs of Indian rivers is west flowing?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
Narmada and Tapi are the prominent west-flowing rivers in India. Both originate in central India and flow westward into the Arabian Sea, contrary to the majority of Indian rivers which flow eastward. Their westward flow is due to the geological structure of the rift valleys in which they are situated.

Extra Information:

  1. Narmada originates from Amarkantak Plateau in Madhya Pradesh, while Tapi originates from the Satpura range.
  2. These rivers have formed estuaries instead of deltas due to their swift flow and hard rock beds.
  3. Major west-flowing rivers like Narmada and Tapi are vital for hydroelectric power and irrigation

question:
Match the following dams with the rivers on which they are built.

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

option_2: a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-v, e-iv
option_3: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i, e-v
option_4: a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-v, e-i
solution:

  • Nagarjuna Sagar Dam is constructed across the Krishna River in Andhra Pradesh.
  • Sardar Sarovar Dam is located on the Narmada River in Gujarat.
  • Tehri Dam is built on the Bhagirathi River in Uttarakhand.
  • Rana Pratap Sagar Dam is situated on the Chambal River in Rajasthan.

Extra Information:

  1. Tehri Dam is one of the highest dams in the world, known for hydroelectric generation and water storage.
  2. Sardar Sarovar Project is a multipurpose river valley project with irrigation, drinking water, and power benefits.
  3. Hirakud Dam, one of the longest dams in the world, plays a key role in flood control and irrigation in eastern India.

question:
Which of the following rivers is joined by river Chambal from the south?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
The Chambal River flows northward from Madhya Pradesh and joins the Yamuna River near Etawah in Uttar Pradesh. It is the largest tributary of the Yamuna and contributes significantly to its water volume, joining it from the south after flowing through deep ravines and gorges.

Extra Information:

  1. The Chambal River is known for its relatively pollution-free waters and deep gorges that shelter rich wildlife.
  2. The river originates from the Vindhya Range in Madhya Pradesh.
  3. It flows through Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh before meeting the Yamuna in Uttar Pradesh.

question:
Choose the coasts that are running along the Arabian sea.

a. Northern Circars, b. Malabar,

c. Konkan, d. Coromandel

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Only a and c
option_2: a, b and c
option_3: b, c and d
option_4: Only b and c
solution:
The Malabar Coast (Kerala and southern Karnataka) and the Konkan Coast (Maharashtra, Goa, and northern Karnataka) lie along the Arabian Sea. In contrast, the Northern Circars and Coromandel Coast are situated along the eastern coast of India, adjoining the Bay of Bengal.

Extra Information:

  1. The Malabar Coast is known for its backwaters, high rainfall, and spice trade history.
  2. The Konkan Coast features rugged terrain, estuaries, and significant ports like Mumbai.
  3. The Coromandel and Northern Circars coasts lie along the Bay of Bengal, not the Arabian Sea.

question:
Which river flows into the Wular lake in the north and then into Baramulla?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Jhelum River originates from Verinag in Jammu & Kashmir and flows through Srinagar into Wular Lake, which is the largest freshwater lake in India. After exiting the lake, it continues westward and passes through Baramulla, eventually entering Pakistan.

Extra Information:

  1. Jhelum is a major tributary of the Indus River and has strategic significance in Kashmir.
  2. It plays a vital role in irrigation and hydroelectric power in the region.
  3. Important cities like Srinagar and Baramulla lie along its course

question:
Which river originates from ‘Rakshastal north-western tip’ near Mansarovar ?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Sutlej River originates from the north-western tip of Lake Rakshastal, near Mount Kailash and Lake Mansarovar in Tibet. It is the longest of the five rivers of Punjab and a major tributary of the Indus River. It enters India through Himachal Pradesh and flows into Pakistan.

Extra Information:

  1. The Sutlej is the easternmost tributary of the Indus River system.
  2. It supports major irrigation projects like the Bhakra-Nangal Dam.
  3. It holds religious significance in both Hindu and Buddhist traditions due to its origin near Mount Kailash

question:
In which of the following districts is Baira Siul Dam located ?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Baira Siul Dam is located in the Chamba district of Himachal Pradesh. It is constructed on the Baira River, a tributary of the Ravi River, and is primarily used for hydroelectric power generation under the Baira Siul Hydroelectric Project.

Extra Information:

  1. The dam is the first hydroelectric project undertaken by NHPC (National Hydroelectric Power Corporation).
  2. It has an installed capacity of 198 MW.
  3. The project contributes significantly to electricity supply in northern India

question:
Choose the correct statement about the peninsular rivers.

a. The Narmada rises in the Malwa plateau.

b. The Godavari rises from the slopes of the Western Ghats near Nashik.

c. The Mahanadi rises in the highlands of Chhattisgarh.

d. The Krishna rises from a spring near Mahabaleshwar.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Only a, b and c
option_2: Only a, c and d
option_3: a, b, c and d
option_4: Only b, c and d
solution:
The correct statements are:

(b) The Godavari rises from the slopes of the Western Ghats near Nashik in Maharashtra.

(c) The Mahanadi originates in the highlands of Chhattisgarh.

(d) The Krishna originates from a spring near Mahabaleshwar in Maharashtra.

Statement (a) is incorrect because the Narmada originates from the Amarkantak Plateau, not the Malwa Plateau.

Extra Information:

  1. The Narmada and Tapi are notable for flowing westward into the Arabian Sea.
  2. Most peninsular rivers like Godavari, Krishna, and Mahanadi flow eastward into the Bay of Bengal.
  3. These rivers are largely rainfed and show seasonal flow patterns.

question:
Which of the following statements is NOT correct about River Ganga ?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: River Ganga flows from the Himalayas all the way to the Bay of Bengal
option_2: River Ganga in India is more than2500 km long and is the most populated river basin in the world
option_3: River Ganga and its river basin support lots of wonderful wildlife, particularly river dolphins, otters, freshwater turtles, and gharials
option_4: The water level of River Ganga never depends on monsoon and climatic condition of the Himalaya.
solution:
Statement (d) is incorrect because the water level of River Ganga significantly depends on monsoon rains and the climatic conditions of the Himalayas, especially due to glacial meltwaters feeding the river during summer months. Monsoon variability directly affects its volume, flow rate, and flood cycles.

Extra Information:

  1. The Ganga is over 2,500 km long, originating from the Gangotri glacier in Uttarakhand.
  2. It is considered one of the most populous river basins in the world, supporting over 400 million people.
  3. It sustains diverse wildlife including Ganges river dolphins, gharial, and freshwater turtles.

question:
In which district of Uttarakhand does the Ramganga river originate from the Doodhatoli ranges?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
The Ramganga river originates from the Doodhatoli ranges located in the Pauri Garhwal district of Uttarakhand. These ranges lie in the middle Himalayas, and the river begins its journey here before flowing through various regions including Jim Corbett National Park and eventually merging with the Ganga.

Extra Information:

  1. The Ramganga river is a tributary of the Ganga and flows predominantly through Uttarakhand and Uttar Pradesh.
  2. It is crucial for irrigation and hydroelectric power, with projects like the Ramganga Multipurpose Project.
  3. The river plays an important ecological role in Jim Corbett National Park, supporting its rich biodiversity.

question:
Trishulganga is a stream of the river:

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
Trishulganga is a stream of the Gandak river. It originates in the high Himalayas and joins the Gandak, which is an important tributary of the Ganga river system. The Trishulganga contributes to the flow of the Gandak, especially during the monsoon season when glacial melt increases.

Extra Information:

  1. The Gandak river is known as Narayani in Nepal and enters India in Bihar.
  2. It is formed by the confluence of the Kaligandaki and Trishulganga rivers in Nepal.
  3. The Gandak basin is significant for irrigation and hydroelectric projects in both Nepal and India.

question:
The drainage basin of the Godavari river is present in which of the following states of India ?

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)
option_1: Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Kerala, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu
option_2: Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka, and Odisha
option_3: Chhattisgarh, Andhra Pradesh, Kerala, Kamataka, and Tamil Nadu
option_4: Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and Odisha
solution:
The drainage basin of the Godavari river is present in Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka, and Odisha. The Godavari is India’s second longest river and flows eastward, draining a vast area across central and southern India before emptying into the Bay of Bengal.

Extra Information:

  1. The Godavari river originates from Trimbak Plateau in Maharashtra.
  2. It forms a large delta in Andhra Pradesh, known for its agricultural productivity.
  3. The basin supports multiple hydropower and irrigation projects, like the Polavaram Project.

question:
With which neighbouring country did India sign the Farakka Treaty in 1996for sharing of the Ganga Waters and on augmenting its flows?

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
India signed the Farakka Treaty in 1996 with Bangladesh for the sharing of the Ganga waters and augmenting its flows. The treaty ensures the equitable distribution of Ganga waters between India and Bangladesh during the dry season, especially around the Farakka Barrage region in West Bengal.

Extra Information:

  1. The treaty is valid for 30 years, from 1996 to 2026.
  2. It was signed to resolve water-sharing disputes related to Farakka Barrage, built to divert water to the Hooghly River.
  3. A Joint River Commission was established to facilitate cooperation and monitoring between the two nations.
